title: Home
text:
H₂aláh₂! Welcome to the homepage for Andrew & Brenna Byrd’s An Immersive Introduction to Proto-Indo-European.





At this site, there are three tabs to click on:

Nominals: paradigms for nouns, adjectives, and pronouns
Verbs: paradigms for verbs
Lexicon: a complete lexicon of PIE, as used in the PIE novellas.

Please reach out to Andrew Byrd if you any issues or questions.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Today’s plan

What PIE grammar is “like” (big picture)
How to use the novella website (where everything is)
How we translate (workflow + practice)

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
section: What you should be able to do by the end
text:
What you should be able to do by the end

Explain how PIE builds meaning with roots + morphology
Use the website to find:

a word in the lexicon
its paradigm
audio + gloss

Begin to translate the story, K̂orh₂ikós and the Snake

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
PIE is “morphology-heavy”
English often uses: - word order - helper words
PIE often uses: - endings (case/number/gender; person/number/tense/aspect/mood) - stem alternations (ablaut) - derivational morphology (suffixes)

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
The basic units

Root: core meaning (e.g. *bʰer- ‘to carry’)
Stem: root + suffix + ablaut grade (e.g. *bʰére- ‘carry’, present stem)
Ending: tells you the grammatical job (e.g. *-ti, 3rd singular)

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Nouns: what you track
For each nominal form, try to identify:

Case (what role?)
Number (sg/du/pl)
Gender (m/f/n)
Stem class (o-stem, eh₂-stem, root noun, etc.)

Translation habit:
Find the ending → infer case/number → decide syntactic role.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
section: The “cases in one slide” (quick functional map)
text:
The “cases in one slide” (quick functional map)

Nominative: subject (“the wolf”)
Accusative: direct object / motion-goal (“see the wolf”)
Genitive: possession / “of” (“tail of the wolf”)
Dative: recipient / “to/for”
Instrumental: means (“with a spear”)
Ablative: source (“from the house”)
Locative: location (“in the house”)
Vocative: address (“O wolf!”)

(You’ll add nuance later; this is enough to start.)

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Verbs: what you track

Person/number: 1/2/3; sg/du/pl
Tense/aspect: present, aorist, perfect
Mood: indicative, imperative, optative, subjunctive
Voice: active, mediopassive

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
PIE syntax (the version we’ll use)

Default is often described as SOV-ish, but it’s flexible.
Endings carry a lot of the load, so word order can be freer.

When translating:
1) identify verbs
2) identify subjects/objects via case
3) find other nominals and words to complete your translation

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Ablaut (only what you need today)
You’ll mainly see: - e-grade vs o-grade vs zero-grade
Today, treat it like: - “same root, different vowel shape” - don’t panic; use the lexicon + paradigm pages to confirm

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
The site is your “decipherment machine”
Three core pages:

Text page (the story): read + click
Lexicon: meanings + stems + audio + notes
Paradigms/Grammar: endings and full inflection tables

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Open the site
Go ahead and open the site. You’ll find three basic page links at the top.

Nominals: https://winjapati.github.io/pie_time/nominals.html
Verbs: https://winjapati.github.io/pie_time/verbs.html
Lexicon: https://winjapati.github.io/pie_time/lexicon.html

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
How to “read” the text page
What you’ll do repeatedly:

Hover / click a word (if enabled)

Look for:

lemma
gloss
morphology hints
audio (if present)

If stuck:

jump to Lexicon entry
then to Paradigm

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Lexicon entry: what matters most
When you open an entry, scan in this order:

Gloss (rough meaning)
Part of speech
Stem info (strong/weak stem; thematic vs athematic)
Paradigm name (tells you where to find endings)

If descendants are listed, treat them as memory hooks, not proof.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Paradigm page: what you’re extracting
From a paradigm table you want:

the exact ending in your form
what that ending means (case/number or person/number/etc.)
any alternations you must copy (accent, ablaut, strong/weak stem)

Rule: Do not “guess an ending” if the paradigm table is available.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
A concrete “site workflow” slide
When you hit an unknown form:
Text page → click word → if not enough → Lexicon → Paradigm → back to text → translate
Do this fast and repeatedly.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Translation is a 3-pass process
Pass 1: morphology (mechanical) - identify endings - label case/number/gender or person/number/etc.
Pass 2: syntax (structural) - decide who did what to whom
Pass 3: English (stylistic) - reorder, add “the/a”, smooth it out

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Your translation worksheet format (copy this)
Line: (copy PIE line)



Word
Lemma
Morphology
Literal gloss
Notes












Then a final line:
Proposed translation: …

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
section: What counts as “good” at this stage
text:
What counts as “good” at this stage
Good = you can justify: - why you think something is nominative/accusative/etc. - why the verb is 3sg/3pl/etc. - where each meaning came from (lexicon vs inference)
Not required yet: - elegant literary English - perfect idioms

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
In-class mini lab (10–15 minutes)
In pairs:

Choose one sentence from today’s section

Fill the table for every word

Make a literal translation

Then produce a smooth translation

Be ready to defend one tricky decision

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Common beginner errors (avoid these)

Trusting English word order too early
Ignoring case endings (“it looks like an object…”)
Translating word-by-word without syntax
Forgetting to check the paradigm page

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Whole-class debrief prompts

What was the main verb?
Where did you find the subject?
What ending was the “key” clue?
What did the lexicon not tell you that you had to infer?

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Exit ticket (2 minutes)
On a notecard / LMS:

One thing endings let PIE do that English doesn’t

The exact website path you used when stuck

One form you translated + how you identified its case/person

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
section: If we have time: speed drill
text:
If we have time: speed drill
I will project 5 forms.
You call out:

noun: case/number (and gender if obvious)
verb: person/number (and tense/aspect label in our system)

No English translation needed—just analysis.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Next time

More on:

adjective-noun agreement
pronouns and clitics (if relevant to your text)
building a “translation memory” for repeated forms

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
PIE has lots of forms
English often uses:

word order:

The boy hugged the tree.
The tree hugged the boy.

helper words

The boy can hug the tree.
The boy will hug the tree.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
PIE has lots of forms
PIE often uses:
- endings - nominals: case/number/gender - verbs: person/number/tense/aspect/mood - stem alternations (ablaut) - derivational morphology (suffixes)

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
PIE often uses:

endings

nominals: case/number/gender
verbs: person/number/tense/aspect/mood

stem alternations (ablaut)
derivational morphology (suffixes)

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
English often uses:

prepositions:

The boy is in the tree.
The boy is next to the tree.
The boy runs away from the tree.
The boy runs to the tree.
The boy carves into the tree with a knife.
The boy plucks apples from the tree for his mom.



locations of nominals in space and time, or how they relate to other words in the sentence

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
The basic units
Put it together:

bʰéreti ‘he/she/it carries’

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
The basic units
You can change the ending:

bʰéresi ‘you carry’

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
The basic units
You can change the stem:

bʰoréyeti ‘(s)he makes (someone) carry’

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
The basic units
Or the root:

léĝeti ‘(s)he gathers’

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Nominals

Nouns
Adjectives
Pronouns

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Nominals

Case (what role?)
Number (sg/du/pl)
Gender (m/f/n)
Stem class (o-stem, eh₂-stem, root noun, etc.) <– more on this later!

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Nominals

Case (what role?)
Number (sg/du/pl)
Gender (m/f/n)
Stem class (o-stem, eh₂-stem, root noun, etc.)


When translating:
Find the ending → identify case/number/gender → identify word’s function in the sentence.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
PIE Cases

Nominative: subject (“the wolf”)
Vocative: address (“yo wolf!”)
Accusative: direct object / motion-goal (“see the wolf”)
Instrumental: means (“with a wolf”)
Dative: recipient / “to/for the wolf”
Ablative: source (“from the wolf”)
Genitive: possession / “of” (“tail of the wolf”)
Locative: location (“in/on/at the wolf”)

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
PIE Cases



Case
PIE form
Function / Meaning




Nominative
wĺ̥kʷos
“the wolf” (subject)


Vocative
wĺ̥kʷe
“yo, wolf!” (address)


Accusative
wĺ̥kʷom
“the wolf” (object)


Instrumental
wĺ̥kʷoh
“with a wolf”


Dative
wĺ̥kʷōy
“to / for the wolf”


Ablative
wĺ̥kʷōd
“from the wolf”


Genitive
wĺ̥kʷosyo
“of the wolf”


Locative
wĺ̥kʷoi
“in / on / at the wolf”

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Verbs: what you track

Person/number
Tense/aspect
Mood
Voice

When translating:
Figure out who’s doing the action from the verb’s ending first. From there, figure out the tense, etc.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
The Novella Website
Access at https://winjapati.github.io/pie_time/

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
PIE Word Order

Often characterize as SOV (subject + object + verb), but it’s very flexible.

Endings carry a lot of the load, so word order can be freer.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Using the Nominals Page

This is where you can access paradigms for nouns, adjectives, and pronouns
Click on “View” –> “Nouns” –> o-stems (masculine)

this gives you the endings for masculine o-stems

Click on “Example noun” –> h₁ék̂wos – ‘horse’

this gives you all of the forms for ‘horse’

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Using the Verbs Page

This is where you can access paradigms for verbs
Click on “View” –> “Present paradigms”
Click on “Verb” –> h₁ey- – to go

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Using the Lexicon Page

Here you can access the PIE lexicon (vocabulary), organized by chapter within the novella

You also have access to vocab not in the novellas

Click on a noun: h₂ózdos – ‘twig, branch, stick’

POS, gender, pronunciation (+ audio file)
Full paradigm

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Activity

Find the:

nominative singular of ‘house’
third singular of ‘to be’
genitive singular of ‘father’

What are the words which mean:

‘day, morning’
‘sheep’
‘granddaughter’

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
section: Common beginner errors to watch out for
text:
Common beginner errors to watch out for

Trusting English word order too early
Ignoring case endings (“it looks like an object…”)
Translating word-by-word without syntax
Forgetting to check the paradigm page

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Immersive PIE Text

H₁ésti h₁ógʷʰis. Só h₂wésti dʰəĝʰmí.
H₁ésti gʷṓws. Sáh₂ h₂wésti dʰəĝʰmí.
H₁ésti h₂ówis. Sáh₂ h₂wésti dʰəĝʰmí.
H₁ésti h₂áwis. H₁ésti trózdos. Só h₂wésti drḗw.
H₁ésti h₂áwis. H₁éstik̂órh₂s. Só h₂wésti drḗw.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Immersive PIE Text

H₁ésti dʰǝĝʰmṓ. H₁ésti h₂yuHn̥k̂ós.
Só h₂wésti démi.  H₁nómn̥ h₂yuHn̥k̂ṓy h₁ésti K̂orh₂ikós.
H₁ésti dʰǝĝʰmṓ. H₁ésti h₂yuHn̥k̂áh₂. Sáh₂ h₂wésti démi.
H₁nómn̥ h₂yuHn̥k̂áh₂ay h₁ésti Trózdah₂. 
Trózdah₂ h₁ésti K̂orh₂ikósyo swésōr.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Immersive PIE Text: together

H₁ésti h₁ógʷʰis. Só h₂wésti dʰəĝʰmí.
H₁ésti gʷṓws. Sáh₂ h₂wésti dʰəĝʰmí.
H₁ésti h₂ówis. Sáh₂ h₂wésti dʰəĝʰmí.
H₁ésti h₂áwis. H₁ésti trózdos. Só h₂wésti drḗw.
H₁ésti h₂áwis. H₁ésti k̂órh₂s. Só h₂wésti drḗw.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Immersive PIE Text: in groups

H₁ésti dʰǝĝʰmṓ. H₁ésti h₂yuHn̥k̂ós.
Só h₂wésti démi. H₁nómn̥ h₂yuHn̥k̂ṓy h₁ésti K̂orh₂ikós.
H₁ésti dʰǝĝʰmṓ. H₁ésti h₂yuHn̥k̂áh₂. Sáh₂ h₂wésti démi.
H₁nómn̥ h₂yuHn̥k̂áh₂ay h₁ésti Trózdah₂.
Trózdah₂ h₁ésti K̂orh₂ikósyo swésōr.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Translating PIE

H₂aláh₂. h₁nómn̥ moy H₁inigṓ montóyah₂ h₁esti. Gʷʰégʷʰens pəh₂térm̥ méne. Pékʷeswe mr̥téyey.

How on earth can be begin to translate this?

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Steps to Translate

identify verbs

identify subjects/objects via case

find other nominals and words to complete your translation

shuffle word order to make it more English-like

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
section: Word order in English tells us the subject vs the object
text:
Word order in English tells us the subject vs the object
The boy hugged the tree. - ‘The boy’ is the subject of the sentence. - ‘The tree’ is the object of the sentence.

The subject of a sentence tells us who or what is verbing. The direct object of a sentence tells us who or what is verbed.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
section: Word order in English tells us the role of the nominals in a sentence
text:
Word order in English tells us the role of the nominals in a sentence
The tree hugged the boy.

What is the subject? What is the direct object?

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
section: Languages with case systems use case markers to indicate the role of the nominals:
text:
Languages with case systems use case markers to indicate the role of the nominals:

Latin:

Agricola poetam videt. ‘The farmer sees the poet’
Agricolam poeta videt. ‘The poet sees the farmer’
Poeta agricolam videt. ‘The poet sees the farmer’
Poetam agricola videt. ‘The farmer sees the poet’



Word order is more flexible because the words themselves contain the information about the roles in the sentence.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Discuss with a partner:

Latin:

Agricola poetam videt. ‘The farmer sees the poet’
Agricolam poeta videt. ‘The poet sees the farmer’
Poeta agricolam videt. ‘The poet sees the farmer’
Poetam agricola videt. ‘The farmer sees the poet’



In the sentences above, which ending indicates the nominative case (the subject) and which one is the accusative case (the direct object)?

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
English often uses:

prepositions:

The boy is in the tree.
The boy is next to the tree.
The boy runs away from the tree.
The boy runs to the tree.
The boy carves into the tree with a knife.
The boy plucks apples from the tree for his mom.



indicates locations of nominals in space and time, or how they relate to the subject of the sentence and the action the subject is doing

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
For nominals, PIE often uses:

endings

nominals: case/number/gender



What do we mean by number? Gender?

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Nominals

Case (what role?)
Number (sg/du/pl)
Gender (m/f/n)
Stem class (o-stem, eh₂-stem, root noun, etc.)

When translating:
Find the ending → identify case/number/gender → identify word’s function in the sentence.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
English verbs also use:

endings

The boy hugs the tree.
The boy hugged the tree.

helper words

The boy could hug the tree.
The boy will hug the tree.

helper words and endings

The boy is hugging the tree.
The boy has hugged the tree.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
PIE verbs often use:

endings

person/number/tense/aspect/mood

stem alternations (ablaut)
derivational morphology (suffixes)

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Reminder!

Take notes on a piece of paper
You’ll hand this in for participation credit for the day
You can use your notes on the quiz

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
English often uses word order:

The boy hugged the tree.
The tree hugged the boy.


to indicate the role of a nominal in a sentence

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Subject vs Object
The boy hugged the tree.

‘The boy’ is the subject of the sentence.
‘The tree’ is the object of the sentence.


The subject of a sentence tells us who or what is verbing.
The direct object of a sentence tells us who or what is verbed.

title: An Immersive Introduction to PIE
text:
Languages with Case Systems:

Latin:

Agricola poetam videt. ‘The farmer sees the poet’
Agricolam poeta videt. ‘The poet sees the farmer’
Poeta agricolam videt. ‘The poet sees the farmer’
Poetam agricola videt. ‘The farmer sees the poet’



Word order is more flexible because the words themselves contain the information about the roles in the sentence.
